newsitem.title: TANZANIA: UN expects 500,000 Hutus to quit Tanzania by Dec 25.
newsitem.headline: UN expects 500,000 Hutus to quit Tanzania by Dec 25.

text.p: At least 500,000 Rwandan Hutu refugees in Tanzania will have returned home by Christmas, the U.N. refugee agency UNHCR said on Saturday.

"At the present rate of repatriation, at least half a million refugees will be spending their first Christmas in Rwanda since 1993," UNHCR spokeswoman Judith Melby told Reuters in the northern Tanzanian town of Ngara.
By nightfall on Friday up to 280,000 Rwandans had crossed the border from Tanzania over the past week and there was a 50-km (30-mile) -long column of some 100,000 Hutus edging towards the border.
"It's one long continuous straggle of people. They are going over today and tomorrow," Melby added.
The bulk of an estimated 125,000 refugees from five camps in the Karagwe zone were expected to cross by December 25.
Over half a million Rwandan Hutus fled to Tanzania in 1994. Tutsi rebels drove them out of the country after putting an end to the genocide of minority Tutsis by the Hutu majority.
Tanzania told its 540,000 unwanted guests to leave by the end of the month, encouraged by the mass repatriation of some 600,000 Rwandan refugees from eastern Zaire last month.
Hardline Hutu militiamen, who played a leading role in the genocide and refuse to return to a Tutsi-ruled Rwanda, are being rounded up and put in a special camp by Tanzanian forces.

On Friday, senior UNHCR official Anne Willem Bijleveld asked for an explanation from Tanzanian authorities about an incident on Wednesday in which refugees were beaten and a church in which they were sheltering was burnt down.
UNHCR workers alleged that Tanzanian security officials carried out the attack. The human rights group Amnesty International protested against the incident.
Tanzanian soldiers have manned roadblocks and wielded sticks to force the refugees to return to Rwanda but there have been few reports of violence.
